abstract.text: Collect payments with iPhone and Apple Watch using Apple Pay.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Offering Apple Pay in Your App

inlineContent.text: This sample shows the implementation of an integrated Apple Pay eCommerce experience across iOS and watchOS. The sample app demonstrates how to use the Apple Pay button, display the Apple Pay payment sheet, make payment requests, and accept coupon codes.
The sample ticket booking app implements buying a ticket using Apple Pay in:
An iOS app.
A watchOS app.
A shared
class handles payment in each of the apps.
This sample code project is associated with WWDC21 session

Test Apple Pay payments with this sample by configuring the bundle identifiers and Apple Pay configuration items in Xcode. Doing this requires an Apple developer account. Before building the app, complete these four steps:
Change the bundle ID for each target so that it’s unique for your developer account; change
in the bundle ID to something that represents you or your organization.
In the build settings, update the value of the user-defined
setting to match the prefix of the bundle IDs you changed in step 1. For example, if you changed
in each bundle ID to your organization name, change
in
to the same organization name. Xcode configures the required merchant ID for Apple Pay in each target when you build the project.
Set up the Apple Pay Merchant Identity and Apple Pay Payment Processing certificates. For more information on setting up a merchant identity and processing certificates, see
Set the signing option for the iOS app to “Automatically manage signing.”
Running this app on an iPhone or Apple Watch requires an Apple Pay card. Running in Simulator doesn’t require a card.
Not all Apple Pay features are supported in the iOS simulator. Testing Apple Pay is unsupported in the watchOS simulator.
For more information about processing an Apple Pay payment using a payment platform or merchant bank, see
. To set up your sandbox environment for testing, see

Apple Pay includes pre-built buttons to start a payment interaction, or to set up payment methods. The iOS app displays the payment button if the device can make payments, and it contains at least one payment card; otherwise it displays the button to add a payment.
This sample checks for the ability to make payments using
, and checks for available payment cards using
. Both of these methods are part of

code: class func applePayStatus() -> (canMakePayments: Bool, canSetupCards: Bool) {

inlineContent.text: The iOS app displays the payment button by adding an instance of
The sample app doesn’t display the add button if a device can’t accept payments due to hardware limitations, parental controls, or any other reasons.
The watchOS app adds the button to the storyboard as an instance of

The app defines two shipping methods: delivery with estimated shipping dates and on-site collection. The payment sheet displays the delivery information for the chosen shipping method, including estimated delivery dates. Configuring the dates requires a calendar, start date components, and end date components

code: let shippingStart = calendar.date(byAdding: .day, value: 3, to: today)!
let shippingEnd = calendar.date(byAdding: .day, value: 5, to: today)!

inlineContent.text: Both iOS and watchOS implementations start the payment process by calling the
method of the shared
. Updates to the payment sheet use the completion handlers implemented by both apps. The
method stores the completion handlers because the Apple Pay functionality is asynchronous; and then the method creates an array of
to display the charges on the payment sheet.

code: let ticket = PKPaymentSummaryItem(label: "Festival Entry", amount: NSDecimalNumber(string: "9.99"), type: .final)
let tax = PKPaymentSummaryItem(label: "Tax", amount: NSDecimalNumber(string: "1.00"), type: .final)
let total = PKPaymentSummaryItem(label: "Total", amount: NSDecimalNumber(string: "10.99"), type: .final)

inlineContent.text: The app configures a
using the list of payment items and other details.
Next the app displays the payment sheet by calling
with the payment request. Both apps present the payment sheet using
The payment sheet handles all user interactions, including payment confirmation. It requests updates using the completion handlers stored by the
method when a user updates the sheet.
The
class handles coupons by implementing the
protocol method
After the user enters an accepted coupon code, the method adds a new
displaying the discount, and adjusts the
with the discounted total.
This method is wrapped in a conditional compilation flag as watchOS 8 doesn’t support coupon codes.

code: // The `didChangeCouponCode` delegate method allows you to make changes when the user enters or updates a coupon code.
let couponDiscountItem = PKPaymentSummaryItem(label: "Coupon Code Applied", amount: NSDecimalNumber(string: "-2.00"))
let updatedTax = PKPaymentSummaryItem(label: "Tax", amount: NSDecimalNumber(string: "0.80"), type: .final)
let updatedTotal = PKPaymentSummaryItem(label: "Total", amount: NSDecimalNumber(string: "8.80"), type: .final)
// If the coupon code is valid, update the summary items.
// If the user doesn't enter a code, return the current payment summary items.
// If the user enters a code, but it's not valid, we can display an error.
let couponError = PKPaymentRequest.paymentCouponCodeInvalidError(localizedDescription: "Coupon code is not valid.")

inlineContent.text: When the user authorizes the payment, the system calls the
method of the
protocol. Your handler confirms that the shipping address meets the criteria needed, and then calls the completion handler to report success or failure of the payment.
The sample code contains a comment at the place you add code for processing the payment.

code: func paymentAuthorizationController(_ controller: PKPaymentAuthorizationController, didAuthorizePayment payment: PKPayment, handler completion: @escaping (PKPaymentAuthorizationResult) -> Void) {
// Perform basic validation on the provided contact information.
let pickupError = PKPaymentRequest.paymentShippingAddressUnserviceableError(withLocalizedDescription: "Sample App only available in the United States")
// Send the payment token to your server or payment provider to process here.
// Once processed, return an appropriate status in the completion handler (success, failure, and so on).

inlineContent.text: Once the sample app calls the completion handler in the
method, Apple Pay tells the app it can dismiss the payment sheet by calling

. iOS and watchOS both handle dismissing the sheet as appropriate for each platform. In the iOS app, if payment succeeds the completion handler performs a segue to display a new view controller. If the payment fails, it remains on the payment sheet so the user can attempt payment with a different card or correct any issues.

abstract.text: Fulfill the requirements to provide Apple Pay as a payment option on your website or in your app.
A button that you can use to trigger payments through Apple Pay.
Process Apple Pay payments in your app, and create and distribute passes for the Wallet app.
An object that presents a sheet that prompts the user to authorize a payment request.
Returns whether the user can make payments.
Returns whether the user can make payments through the specified network.
Methods that let you respond to user interactions with your payment authorization controller.
Tells the delegate that the user authorized the payment request, and asks for a result.
Tells the delegate that the user changed the payment method, and asks for an updated payment request.
Tells the delegate that payment authorization has completed.
An object that displays a button either to trigger payments through Apple Pay or to prompt the user to set up a card.
An object that represents a request for payment, including details about payment-processing capabilities, the payment amount, and shipping information.
An object that defines a summary item in a payment request, taxes, discounts, shipping, a grand total, and the like.
Request and process Apple Pay payments in your app.
Check regional regulations for possible requirements for your Apple Pay-based implementation.
Fulfill the requirements to provide Apple Pay as a payment option on your website or in your app.
